title: R43398
content: The federal government has supported educational statistics for over 150 years, with the creation of the National Institute of Education (NIE) and the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) in the 1970s. The Institute of Education Sciences (IES) now oversees federal educational research and statistics efforts since replacing the Office of Educational Research and Improvement (OERI) in 2002. The federal government's educational research and statistics efforts are overseen by the Institute of Education Sciences (IES), established in 2002 through the Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA). ESRA created IES as an independent institute within the Department of Education, headed by a Director appointed by the President. The National Board of Educational Sciences (NBES) advises the Director on institute policies and research priorities. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) in 2002 to oversee federal educational research and statistics. The National Board of Educational Sciences (NBES) advises the Director on institute policies and research priorities. ESRA also created three National Education Centers: the National Center for Education Research (NCER), the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES), and the National Center for Education Evaluation and Regional Assistance (NCEE). P.L. 108-446 added a fourth center, the National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER), under IES. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) in 2002, which includes the National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER). ESRA also enacted two additional acts - the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) and the National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA). ETAA authorizes grants for technical assistance activities, while NAEPAA authorizes national and state assessments in reading and mathematics for grades 4, 8, and 12. These changes led to the creation of an independent research institute and emphasized "scientifically-based" practices. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) established the Institute of Education Sciences (IES) in 2002, creating an independent research institute with "scientifically-based" standards. ESRA provides more freedom for IES compared to the previous Office of Educational Research and Improvement (OERI) within the Department of Education (ED), while also introducing greater oversight through a technical panel (NBES). ESRA specifies standards for educational research, including scientifically based and valid research. ESRA, along with other authorizing legislation, sets standards for educational research supported by IES. The House passed H.R. 4366 in the 113th Congress, and the Senate passed a similar bill, S. 227, in the 114th Congress. Funding for these programs has continued through annual appropriations. The House and Senate passed bills (H.R. 4366 and S. 227) in different Congresses to reauthorize ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA, amending various provisions related to education research. The report describes these programs and authorities established by the legislation, P.L. 107-279, and recent legislative actions. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) is organized in alignment with legislation P.L. 107-279, containing provisions authorizing IES, NBES, and National Education Centers. ESRA aims to provide national leadership in expanding knowledge of education and improving academic achievement through research. IES provides information on education progress and program effectiveness to various stakeholders. The Institute of Education Sciences (IES) provides information on education progress and program effectiveness to stakeholders. The IES Director is appointed by the President with Senate approval and is responsible for proposing research priorities, conducting evaluations, and ensuring activities are objective and nonpartisan. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) outlines duties such as proposing research priorities, establishing review procedures, advising on research matters, and ensuring objectivity and neutrality. ESRA also authorizes the National Board for Education Sciences (NBES) to advise the Director on IES policies, approve research priorities, funding decisions, and assess progress for improvement. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) authorizes the National Board for Education Sciences (NBES) to advise the Director on IES policies, approve research priorities, funding decisions, and assess progress for improvement. ESRA specifies requirements related to the composition, qualification, compensation, and travel expenses of the Board members. IES is composed of four research centers, each headed by a Commissioner appointed by the Director for a term not to exceed six years. The Education Sciences Reform Act (ESRA) authorizes four research centers under IES, each headed by a Commissioner appointed for a term not exceeding six years. NCER's mission is to sponsor research for high-quality education, student achievement improvement, closing achievement gaps, and enhancing postsecondary education access. NCER, as outlined in ESRA, is responsible for maintaining peer-review processes, proposing research plans, implementing valid research, ensuring relevance to education practice and policy, and disseminating research findings. The Commissioner of NCER is authorized to support national research initiatives. The Commissioner of NCER is responsible for supporting national research initiatives on various education topics through research and development centers. These centers receive competitive grants for up to five years to address areas of national need, with the possibility of continuation grants for a maximum of 10 years. The Commissioner of NCER oversees national research initiatives through competitive grants for research and development centers. Grants are awarded for up to five years, with the potential for continuation grants for a maximum of 10 years. NCES is authorized to collect and analyze education information with high methodological standards. NCES is authorized to collect and analyze education information with high methodological standards for at least five years. Its primary duty is to report education statistics objectively and in a timely manner, ensuring reports are relevant and useful to practitioners, researchers, policymakers, and the public. Other duties include publishing reports on collected statistics, setting standards for state educational agencies, and acquiring data systems. The duties of NCES, as specified in ESRA, include publishing reports on education statistics, setting standards for state educational agencies, and collecting data on various topics such as student achievement and teacher supply. The Commissioner is authorized to carry out these duties through grants, contracts, and technical assistance. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) collects data on various education-related topics such as student achievement, teacher supply, school violence, financing, management, and the use of educational technology. Data must be disaggregated by gender, race, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) collects data on education-related topics such as student achievement, teacher supply, school violence, financing, and technology use. Data must be disaggregated by various demographics for decision-making purposes. ESRA Part D authorizes NCEE to support evaluation and technical assistance for federal education programs. The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) collects data on education-related topics. ESRA Part D authorizes the National Center for Education Evaluation (NCEE) to conduct evaluations of federal education programs to determine their impact on student academic achievement in core academic areas. NCEE is authorized to award grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements, provide technical assistance, and ensure evaluations adhere to high standards of quality. The National Center for Education Evaluation (NCEE) is responsible for evaluating federal education programs under Title I of ESEA and supplementing other program evaluations. NCEE must establish evaluation methodology, adhere to high standards, and provide technical assistance through the Regional Educational Laboratories (REL) program. The Director of IES contracts with 10 RELs to serve children nationwide, with specific objectives and measurable indicators to assess their performance. RELs conduct applied research and development to support education evaluations. The Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs) are contracted by the Director of IES to serve children nationwide. They conduct applied research, development, dissemination, and technical assistance activities to meet the needs of the regions they serve. The central mission of RELs involves providing training, technical assistance, and scientifically valid research on teaching methods, assessment tools, and curriculum frameworks for various content areas. They also facilitate communication between educational experts, school officials, teachers, parents, and other stakeholders. The duties of the Regional Educational Laboratories (RELs) include facilitating communication between educational experts, school officials, teachers, parents, and librarians to assist schools in meeting state education goals, conducting applied research, and engaging in dissemination activities. The Commissioner of NCEE must provide independent evaluations of each REL and share the results with relevant committees of Congress, the NSEB, and the appropriate REL. Part E of ESRA authorizes NCSER to sponsor research to improve the developmental needs of infants, toddlers, and children with disabilities. Part E of ESRA authorizes NCSER to sponsor research to improve the developmental, educational, and transitional outcomes of infants, toddlers, and children with disabilities under IDEA. NCSER's duties include identifying scientifically based practices and services to support learning, academic achievement, and participation in general education settings. The National Center for Special Education Research (NCSER) is responsible for identifying evidence-based practices to support academic achievement and participation in general education for children with disabilities. NCSER also focuses on aligning state standards, addressing overidentification and underidentification of children with disabilities, improving personnel preparation, and addressing the special needs of limited English proficient children with disabilities through grants and research activities. NCSER awards grants for special education research activities in accordance with NCER standards. ESRA Part F outlines provisions for funding, confidentiality, data availability, and staffing considerations. $400 million was authorized for FY2003 activities, with additional funding for the following years. $400 million in appropriations were authorized under ESRA for activities and $100 million for RELs for FY2003 and subsequent years. Funding continued post FY2008 through annual appropriations. P.L. 107-279 includes the Educational Technical Assistance Act (ETAA) for grants supporting technical assistance, evaluation, and statewide data systems. The Secretary can award at least 20 grants for comprehensive centers across 10 regions to work with SEAs, LEAs, and schools. The Secretary is authorized to award grants for comprehensive centers for technical assistance to local entities across 10 regions. Each center must work with SEAs, LEAs, and schools in its region, providing training, professional development, and disseminating information to improve academic achievement. Coordination with other agencies and technical assistance providers is required. The Secretary awards grants for comprehensive centers to provide technical assistance to local entities. Each center coordinates with various agencies and providers, establishes an advisory board, and reports annually. The Secretary conducts evaluations and may also grant funds to SEAs for statewide data systems to manage student data efficiently. The Secretary awards grants for comprehensive centers to provide technical assistance to local entities in managing student data efficiently and accurately. Funding for these activities was authorized in FY2003 and continued through annual appropriations legislation. Title III of P.L. 107-279 established the National Assessment Governing Board and the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP). The National Assessment Governing Board (NAGB) was established by the National Assessment of Educational Progress Authorization Act (NAEPAA) to oversee the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP). NAEP includes national and state assessment programs, a long-term trend study, and a trial urban district assessment program. Participation in the NAEP assessment is voluntary for students. The National Assessment Governing Board oversees the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP), which includes national and state assessment programs. Participation in the NAEP assessment is voluntary for students, schools, and local educational agencies. The Assessment Board formulates policy guidelines for NAEP with input from various stakeholders. The Assessment Board, overseen by the National Assessment Governing Board, sets duties for selecting subject areas, developing achievement levels, objectives, and test specifications for valid and reliable assessments. They involve teachers, curriculum specialists, administrators, parents, and the public in the review process and consult with technical experts to ensure validity and reliability in measuring student academic achievement. The National Assessment Governing Board ensures the validity and reliability of assessment items for grades 4, 8, and 12 in academic subjects. They develop guidelines for reporting results, standards for comparisons, and plan the release of reports. Funding for these activities was authorized until FY2008. During the 113th and 114th Congress, bills were passed to reauthorize ESRA, ETAA, and NAEPAA, amending provisions related to IES independence, research standards, technical assistance, evaluation, privacy protection, student assessment oversight, and IES accountability. Both H.R. 4366 and S. 227 proposed changes and differences in these areas.
